awd_titl_txt: Intelligent Soft Robot Mobility in the Real World
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is the creation of soft, snake-like robots that can navigate through real environments with confined spaces, fragile objects, clutter, rough and/or granular surfaces. The project includes three research thrusts, namely modular mechanical design of a segmented snake robot, low-level algorithms for the robot to execute simple functional motion primitives, and high-level planning algorithms to construct appropriate sequences of motion primitives in order to meet mission objectives. Because they can deform in response to their environment, soft robots can adapt to unexpected circumstances more robustly than a rigid robot. Their high compliance gives soft robots the potential to safely and effectively interact with obstacles, and even to use surrounding objects as aids to locomotion. Robots that embrace touch instead of avoiding it could transform applications through physical human-robot partnership. Specifically, the direct use of assistive and intelligent third-hand devices or soft supernumerary arms could seamlessly provide new capabilities to workers or the disabled. Human-robot collaboration in industry could improve efficiency, reduce cost, and increase the global competitiveness of US manufacturing. 

The objective of this project is to endow soft robots with intelligence in navigating real-world environments autonomously using a hierarchical control approach from low-level functions and motion primitives to high-level locomotion tasks. The tasks to be accomplished towards this objective include a modular soft robot architecture with distributed actuation, high-density deformation sensing, embedded module-level control, and inter-module communication; control methods to achieve reliable and repeatable dynamic module responses, to optimize performance over time based on past iterations, and to provide high-level decision making by stochastic abstraction and control of the system in its environment through data-driven modeling; and motion planning and locomotion algorithms to find curvature bounded trajectories through cluttered environments, exploit contact to achieve obstacle aided locomotion, and 3-D motion primitives to operate on granular surfaces.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this proposal was to endow soft robots with intelligence in navigating realistic environments. The scientific and technological focus was to address system level challenges in physical and computational capabilities of a soft robot by providing a complete actuation, sensing, control, and intelligence solution in a highly scalable modular setting. The target physical system for this research was a modular soft robotic snake. The project developed techniques for a) the design, fabrication, and understanding mechanical capabilities of a modular soft robotic snake architecture; b) soft robotic control; and c) soft robotic locomotion, taking into account the unique properties of a soft slender snake-like robotic mobility platform. 

Soft snake robotics is an important research topic with a wide range of applications, including inspection in confined spaces, search-and-rescue, and disaster response. However, modeling, fabrication, planning and control of soft snake robots have been challenging problems due to the difficult-to-model and stochastic dynamics, inherent nonlinearity, and limited sensing capabilities. This project developed novel 2D and 3D soft robotic modules and studied low-level feedback control of the modules for improved performance. Ability to lift off the body at predefined locations with 3D locomotion gaits provided improved frictional behaviors and achieved different locomotion modes such as sidewinding. Using module-level control of curvature wave amplitudes, an iterative learning controller led to curvature bounded well-defined trajectories and an adaptive bounding box approach to be able to plan obstacle-free trajectories of soft robotic snakes despite their complex, nonlinear, and uncertain locomotion that arises from traveling curvature waves, complex frictional interactions with the surface, and manufacturing variations between modules. 

The project also developed a novel learning and control framework for 2D soft snake robots to achieve robust goal tracking and obstacle-aided navigation. The learning-based controller integrated  bio-inspired central pattern generators to generate rhythmic, energy-efficient locomotion, and combined such low-level controllers with deep reinforcement learning at the high level for intelligent goal tracking and obstacle-aware navigation. Furthermore, this project designed and fabricated a 3D pneumatic soft robotic snake able to perform lateral undulation, sidewinding, and step climbing locomotion. In order to eliminate the unpredictable deformation and buckling under external force, the project designed a flexible sheath wrapping around the actuator. As a result, the robotic snake becomes more controllable and capable of 3D locomotion against gravity. This project also paved the way towards extensions to achieve a salamander-inspired modular continuum mobile robot with an origami structure, which is capable of traversing highly unconstructed terrain. A kinematics model is constructed for the modular continuum mobile robot and can be used for motion planning and control. The research included work on deformation sensing to detect the arc parameters (curvature, bending plane, and arc length) of a soft section resulting in an effective and high-speed 2-DOF magnetic bend sensing for soft bodies through a constant curvature system. We developed a probabilistic particle filter paired with magnetic simulations to produce highly accurate and fast pose information for parameter-constrained magnets.

In addition to design, fabrication, planning and control, this project also developed a GPU-enabled high-fidelity simulator for 2D and 3D soft snake robots. The simulators for soft snake robots can be extended to other soft robotic systems and thus facilitate future study of nonlinear control and reinforcement learning algorithms to be developed for soft robots. The project demonstrated similar performance of a locomotion controller for both simulated and real 2D snake robots.

To date, this research has contributed to thirteen peer-reviewed publications, with two journal papers under review. Several graduate and undergraduate students and a postdoctoral associate were trained in the design and fabrication, machine learning, motion planning, and control of soft robots. The project results have been disseminated with publications, workshops, lab tours, and summer programs at WPI.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Cagdas D Onal
